questions.question: What is the displacement at time t = 2 seconds?
questions.explanation: At t = 2 seconds, the graph shows a displacement of 10 meters from the origin.

questions.question: What is the displacement at time t = 5 seconds?
questions.explanation: At t = 5 seconds, the displacement is 25 meters from the origin.

questions.question: What is the velocity of the object?
questions.explanation: Velocity = slope = rise/run. Using the endpoints: (25 m - 0 m) / (5 s - 0 s) = 25/5 = 5 m/s

questions.question: What is the nature of the motion shown in the graph?
questions.explanation: The straight line with constant slope indicates constant velocity motion.

questions.question: What is the displacement at time t = 0 seconds?
questions.explanation: The graph starts at the origin, so at t = 0 seconds, displacement = 0 m.

questions.question: How far does the object travel between t = 1 second and t = 4 seconds?
questions.explanation: At t = 1s: 5 m, at t = 4s: 20 m. Distance = 20 - 5 = 15 m

questions.question: What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: Since velocity is constant, acceleration = 0 m/s².

questions.question: If the motion continues at the same rate, what will be the displacement at t = 8 seconds?
questions.explanation: At 5 m/s, in 8 seconds: displacement = 5 m/s × 8 s = 40 m

questions.question: Conceptual — What does a straight line on a displacement-time graph indicate?
questions.explanation: A straight line indicates constant slope, which means constant velocity.

questions.question: Conceptual — How is velocity calculated from a displacement-time graph?
questions.explanation: Velocity = change in displacement / change in time = slope of the displacement-time graph.
